results.title: Uber and Lyft Ramp Up Legislative Efforts to Shield Business Model
results.abstract: Gig economy companies are backing state laws in New York and elsewhere that would cement drivers’ status as contractors in exchange for a union.

multimedia.caption: Driving for Uber in Manhattan. Gig companies like Uber and Lyft have long resisted classifying workers as employees.

results.title: What to Know About the Newest iPhone and Android Software
results.abstract: Apple and Google have unveiled phone features designed for an era of hybrid remote and in-person work.

results.title: Young Creators Are Burning Out and Breaking Down
results.abstract: Many people who have found fame on TikTok are struggling with mental health issues.

results.title: Tech Shakes Up the Supermarket
results.abstract: Technology is changing our lives in one of the most ordinary places in America.

results.title: An Onscreen Chat With Hito Steyerl, Art’s Great Screen Skeptic
results.abstract: The German artist’s new exhibition at the Pompidou Center in Paris examines, with bitter humor, how digital technology shapes life offline.

multimedia.caption: “For me it’s a machine,”  Hito Steyerl said of the Pompidou Center. “A big machine, a bone-eating machine.”

results.title: Ohio’s attorney general wants Google to be declared a public utility.
results.abstract: If Google were declared a so-called common carrier like a utility company, it would prevent the company from prioritizing its own products, services and websites in search results.
results.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Cecilia Kang

results.title: YouTube Isn’t the Music Villain Anymore
results.abstract: YouTube seems to have shown that it’s possible to both upend an industry and help make it stronger.

results.title: A widespread internet outage affects major websites.
results.abstract: The sites of the British government, The New York Times and Twitter were among those that were briefly inaccessible for some users.
results.byline: By Jenny Gross and Adam Satariano

results.title: Farewell, Millennial Lifestyle Subsidy
results.abstract: The price for Ubers, scooters and Airbnb rentals is going up as tech companies aim for profitability.

results.title: U.S. Seizes Share of Ransom From Hackers in Colonial Pipeline Attack
results.abstract: Investigators traced 75 Bitcoins worth more than $4 million through nearly two dozen cryptocurrency accounts.
results.byline: By Katie Benner and Nicole Perlroth

multimedia.caption: The cyberattack on Colonial Pipeline last month shut down its computer systems, leading to soaring gas prices and panic buying.

results.title: Apple unveils new privacy features, digital IDs and changes to FaceTime.
results.abstract: Apple’s privacy push has put the company at odds with rivals. Despite protests from some corners of Silicon Valley, Monday’s announcements show that Apple has doubled down on privacy features.
results.byline: By Jack Nicas and Brian X. Chen

results.abstract: If you own a newer Amazon gadget, like a Ring camera or an Echo speaker, you'll be automatically enrolled in a new network called Sidewalk.

results.abstract: Some developers are sick of Apple being a dictator. Apple says it’s protecting us. Let’s dissect this.

results.title: Jeff Bezos Will Fly Aboard Blue Origin’s First Human Trip to Space
results.abstract: Mr. Bezos and his brother, Mark, will be on board when his rocket company launches its first human spaceflight next month, shortly after he steps down as chief executive of Amazon.
results.byline: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Kenneth Chang

results.abstract: The tech giant, which is facing similar scrutiny in the U.S., also said it would make changes to increase transparency of its online ad systems.

results.title: What Happened When Trump Was Banned on Social Media
results.abstract: Since Facebook and Twitter banned him, Donald J. Trump, the former president, has posted statements online far less often. But some of his statements have traveled just as far and wide on social networks.
results.byline: By Davey Alba, Ella Koeze and Jacob Silver

results.title: Graeme Ferguson, Filmmaker Who Helped Create Imax, Dies at 91
results.abstract: He partnered with friends to produce stunning original technology that would give movie viewers an immersive, stadium-like experience.

multimedia.caption: Graeme Ferguson filming a space shuttle launch for the 1982 Imax film “Hail Columbia!” Despite Imax’s stunning technology, Mr. Ferguson struggled for decades to get investors to embrace his vision.

results.title: New York Turns to Smart Thermometers for Disease Detection in Schools
results.abstract: The technology company Kinsa will distribute as many as 100,000 internet-connected thermometers through the city’s elementary schools.

multimedia.caption: The Kinsa internet-connected thermometers have routinely detected the spread of seasonal flu weeks before the C.D.C. And when Covid hit, the company saw unusual spikes in fevers about 18 days before states recorded peaks in deaths.

results.title: Why A.I. Should Be Afraid of Us
results.abstract: Because benevolent bots are suckers. Plus, racism in medical journals, the sperm-count “crisis” and more in the Friday edition of the Science Times newsletter.

results.title: Windows Is No Big Deal. That’s Huge.
results.abstract: Technology is not just a shiny new thing that comes out of a box. Now it’s all around us all of the time.

results.title: Facebook Says Trump’s Ban Will Last at Least 2 Years
results.abstract: The decision denies the former president a megaphone at least through the midterm elections. The suspension was put in place after the Capitol riot in January.

results.byline: By Mike Ives and Paul Mozur

results.title: Facebook Plans to End Hands-Off Approach to Politicians’ Posts
results.abstract: The social network, under pressure since barring former President Donald J. Trump, will no longer automatically give world leaders special treatment.

multimedia.caption: The policy change is a stark one for Facebook, whose chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, previously said he didn’t want the company to be an arbiter of speech.

results.title: White House Warns Companies to Act Now on Ransomware Defenses
results.abstract: An open letter urged them to take many of the defensive steps that the federal government requires of its agencies and contractors.
results.byline: By David E. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth

multimedia.caption: An open letter on Thursday by Anne Neuberger, a deputy national security adviser, noted “a recent shift in ransomware attacks — from stealing data to disrupting operations.”

results.title: Biden Expands Trump-Era Ban on Investment in Chinese Firms Linked to Military
results.abstract: The new order includes firms engaged in making and deploying the surveillance technology used against Muslim minorities and dissidents around the globe.
results.byline: By David E. Sanger and David McCabe

multimedia.caption: Among the firms President Biden listed on Thursday was Huawei, China’s national champion in telecommunications, and the centerpiece of its effort to export 5G networks around the world.

results.title: In Hong Kong, Short-Lived Censorship Hints at a Deeper Standoff
results.abstract: Authorities succeeded in shuttering an activist site for three days. The takedown, and its reversal, presage a battle over internet freedoms.

results.title: Amazon Wants a Lot of New Laws
results.abstract: The tech giant deserves credit for taking on big issues, but what matters is that it follows through to the end.
